messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "peter_r_guinness" <malt99@...>
wrote:
>
> A little info for you about Alice-- It was designed mainly for
> Australians to learn quikscript easily, but it glad to hear that you
> can still benefit from it.

Oh, I am definitely benefiting from it. It is very useful, even for
a speaker of American English. While reading through it I could see
that it was a real labor of love.

Do you mind if I ask you some questions about it? How did you come
up with the idea of only replacing a few Roman letters with QS
symbols at a time? How did you decide on the order the symbols would
be introduced in (ie. which symbols to introduce in which chapter)?
Did you create the tutorial completely by hand, or did you use some
kind of automation to help write it? If you were writing the Alice
tutorial over again, would you do anything differently?

> These tutorials are really just
> introduction tutes, designed to get you started in being able to
read
> quikscript, but it requires alot more reading to become truely
fluent.
>
> I deliberately left out the rhotic 'r' to speed learning for
> Australians.
>
> I considered it best that people learn quikscript by basically
learning
> two versions-- first one based on their own pronunciations and then
> proper international quikscript.

This all sounds quite reasonable to me.

> I had planned to write a follow up tutorial which uses the
> book "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There" which
> starts where the Alice tutes finished and uses the first half of the
> book to adapt Austrlian junior quikscript to an international junior
> quikscript. The last half of the book would be purely for practise
of
> the international version.
>
> The problem is that we don't have an agreed upon international
version.
> This was discussed quite a bit a long time ago-- the main issues is
> what to do with mergers and splits of some accents, particularly the
> differences between the UK accents and the American accents. (eg:
the
> caught/cot merger in General American).

Yeah, I've read some of the discussions in this group on that
subject. It sounds to me like there never will be an "international"
version of QS... at least not one deliberately created by and
adhered to by people on this group.

> I think most would agree that RP could be used as a standard for UK
> English, cause most Britians know what it sounds like and can
imagine
> how to write it. Also most other native English speakers in the
> English Commonwealth (except possibly Canada) can also phonemicly
> emulate RP easily (eg: at the phonemic level there is hardly any
> difference between RP, Australian and New Zealand-- South African
might
> be considered to have a few minor splits though not overly
different. I
> imagine that most Indians who speak English would be close to RP at
the
> phonemic level-- though not sure of this.)
>
> I do support the idea that a true international quickscript should
> include the rhotic 'r' though it is a little difficult for us non-
> rhotic speakers to know where to put them but not overly so. This
> difficulty is probably not as great as that faced by a General
American
> when trying to decided where to use 'Ox', 'Ah' and 'Awe' when
emulating
> RP english.
>
> PS: Could be please inform me of any mistakes/typos in the Alices
> tutorials you find while you are reading them :)

I think I spotted two minor typos in the six chapters I've read so
far. Unfortunately, I didn't make a note of them, but if I run in to
any more I'll send them your way.

--Sergey
